Pros: Good pay, good incentives, smart people.

Pros: An excellent company to work where we will be encouraged and we can share our ideas with our team colleagues.
Cons: Nothing to report about the company.

Review Title: Navigating Kyndryl: Benefits Shine, but Compensation and Management Vary
Pros: Kyndryl has a great vacation and sick-leave policy for full-time employees. They guarantee 7 days of sick time per year with the ability for your manager (or short-term disability) to increase this number. We are also given 4 personal choice holidays, 8 paid holidays, and 15 vacation days. Depending on your role and manager, there is flexibility in your working hours that allow for you to "flex" time when necessary.
Cons: Pay is lower than market value and employees that stay with the company are not given adequate raises to keep up with cost of living, experience, or new hires. A lot of your experience is solely determined by the manager that you have. Some managers are great and some are absolutely terrible.

Pros: Flexible, Flat, Focused, People friendly
Cons: Heavy Mainframe contracts, Negative GP contracts

Review Title: Making it up as they go along, quickly becoming the worst of IBM.
Pros: Great legacy with IBM GTS, as such they have access to a stellar account base. Some good people. They are working hard to provide more comprehensive services. Salaries can be good for some when they don't change the comp plan.
Cons: For some reason they did not protect themselves when the contracts novated over from IBM. So that when IBM raises their prices to Kyndryl, they try and pass it along to their customers even mid-contract with them. This causes a customer sat issue. Lots of sat issues. Not focusing on organic growth but only on the few profitable clients. Old time IBM management employees form a click and protect themselves at the cost of efficiency. There is a lot of people staying in roles where they should be shifted and moved around. Others are promoted prematurely based on old connections. Perhaps they will have a management RIF. Top leaders have exorbitant salaries while they rework the comp plan to focus on GP and reduce commissions to those who own the day to day relationships. ( see my comment above on why that is harsh - they artificially raise allocation on SOW's to increase cost of sales )

Review Title: Miserable culture at Kyndryl- Worst of IBM was spun off
Pros: Some nice people trying to earn a living.
Cons:
They do not pay commissions
DEI is rampant as was imparted by IBM CEO. 
Hangers-on all over the place.
IBM mentality which will drive it into the ground
People are not managed properly. Have no ideas at skillsets as all they do is manage by spreadsheet.
No real products anymore. Just resellers of other's products and services.

Cons: Bonuses and increments are very low...percentages of hikes are single digits.

Review Title: Lack of Diversity on the Communications Team = Unchecked Microagressions
Pros: For me, the salary was great and the bonus was a plus, also!
Cons:
While I was thankful to have collaborated with great people in various areas of the company, two colleagues created one of the most toxic work environments ever. I did not feel supported by the people who were my teammates. To make matters worse, one person blamed their behavior on "being an Aries." 

I couldn't leave that company fast enough.

Pros: Company culture values changing the way it's been from its pre-spin company.
Cons: Still in the beginning phases, lots of stuff to figure out but doing it well.

Pros: Kyndryl's culture of restlessness and empathy sets the tone for employees to feel valued and part of the company's overall strategy. Combined with a commitment to invest in employees' education, you feel like your personal growth is fueling the company's growth too. And Kyndryl certainly checks the box for aligning with my personal sustainability goals.
Cons: With that restlessness comes some impatience, so I have to remind myself that every action taken is part of the overall plan to build Kyndryl's profitability and return the company to growth.

Pros: Flexibility, Nice people to work with
Cons: corporate restructuring and outsourcing caused me to lose my job

Pros: Company isn’t bad. They rarely give raises
Cons: Not enough raises. Workload isn’t terribe

Pros: Not sure if my experience was the same as others because I was hired by a manager who I already knew and she was brought over from another major corporation, but I was paid well and left to do my job remotely without a manager wanting my butt in a seat to prove I can work.
Cons: They try to sell themselves as different than IBM or other older more established corporations but the reality is they took a bunch of IBM old guard and moved them over so a lot of the backdoor dealings are the same. I found upper management to be less than forthright which is expected but not only that they downright lied to hundreds of us for months before we were finally given a measly 2 weeks notice. They prefer offshore Costa Rica or India workers because they are cheaper even if it means a lower quality of work or that others have to do rework.

Pros: In the short time that Kyndryl has been in existence, post separation from IBM, we have been in a constant state of evolution and modernization. Throughout this process the company has provided extensive training and industry certifications, as well as real practical experience in a multitude of critical and in-demand skills. The company has emphasized up-skilling rather than reducing legacy skills and hiring modern skills. We've also seen movement for gender equality through advocacy groups, job title transparency, enhanced HR benefits, and executive training for women.
Cons: Promotions and pay increases are limited regardless of relative contribution.

Pros: Work-life balance, schedule flexibility and respectful attitudes

Pros: Eventually they fire you and you don't have to work there anymore.
Cons: Outages every week that crushed customers. Customers forced to migrate to resell contracts against their will. Terrible support from overstretched collogues that are completely overwhelmed with work. No one knows what the prices of services are, pricing is a joke and takes weeks to get any numbers to customer because of triple/quadruple internal approval gates. Micromanagement to the extreme. You have to report a transcript of customer conversations to management daily. Every action you make has to be reported to management. Everyone faces unbelievable levels of scrutiny. This drives the culture into a cannibalistic frenzy where friends eat friends, and managers consume their own teammates. Delivery is horrendous, the worst delivery team I have every worked with. I think is because they are stretched so, SO thin. "We put people first" is a direct quote from the CEO made the same week they started mass layoffs.

Middle management is mostly a collection of stuttering IBM cast-offs or career tag-a-longs with higher up's . 

Account managers struggle to make things work, locked into unprofitable contracts and told to "make it green".

Review Title: Not a lot of room to grow
Pros: - Pay is great - Benefits are pretty good (i.e. 401k match) - Remote work
Cons: - Not a lot of jobs available internally that match my skill set - Favoritism shown to certain employees - Multiple instances where co-workers have said sexually inappropriate things to me or tried to bully me and they are still employed - When I was brought on, I was hired at the top of my band level. When it came time for the annual increase, they could not increase my salary and they did not want to promote me.

Pros: Library of training courses available. 4% 401k match
Cons: Kyndryl promised upon layoff announcements that we would receive 2 months paycheck to look internally for a new position. A few days before the contract was terminated, they reversed course by telling us there would be no 2 month period to look internally and no paycheck continuing. They lied to all of us on that contract in order to get us to stay to the end, then played games with our lives and families. They make a big show at all the corporate meetings about how important their employees are but it is all lies so don't fall for it.

Pros: In chaos lies opportunity, and the divestiture from IBM has been rough, but productive. Many layers of management and much bureaucracy and garbage process has been cut, we are streamlining, adopting improved tools, generally getting flatter and faster. It's exciting.
Cons: Lost over a hundred years of reputation being divested from IBM. We were Global Technology Solutions, the original IBM prior to the PriceWaterhouseCoopers acquisition, the people who put men on the moon. Being divested felt like being jettisoned by the boat we built.

Pros: Start up culture, with a lot of opportunity to learn / advance quickly
Cons: Very "fast" culture without proper guardrails in place in certain instances. A lot of broken internal tooling which makes information difficult to find, procedures hard to follow, and decision making sometimes becomes difficult due to this. I am confident this will get much better with time.

Review Title: Back to the 90s.. goodbye modern workplace
Pros: I have great management and the business departments are mostly going into the right directions by trying to get more involved with modern cloud technologies.
Cons: Internal processes are living hell right out of a dilbert comic. Their cybersecurity organization tries to control everything. The latest innovation: Tracking your violations against some made-up micromanagement policies like "your can only use approved websites". Each violation gets you a negative point and after a few you get an interview with HR.. I mean - don't they run these things by legal? In a multinational corporations you try to do things like this to your workforce? Regarding Azure.. To even request anything in azure you first need to build a perfect architecture and get it approved through processes that change constantly. And even if you get all the approvals you don't get a subscription (like in every other enterprise this size) but you get only the specific resource you asked for with very limited access to it - everyone who has ever touched azure will know where this goes.. stuff that took me 2 weeks at previous companies now takes 6 months and I don't even know if my resources still work tomorrow because someone decided to change the rules again.. in 8 years working with Azure I never had serious downtime issues.. here it's a weekly thing - I don't even know how you can get downtime in azure..??? Regarding Office365.. They restrict connectors in Power Automate.. so for each flow or power app you create you need to go through an approval process.. you want to use MS forms to get some answers quickly? Nope, you need to work through an 8 week approval process first, get a dedicated environment for it and then you are allowed to use it.. I wouldn't be surprised if they restrict excel formulas next.. (well they probably would if they'd know how to..) It's very sad since the company has great potential but this ancient culture of "we want to do it as we always did" and "our colleagues are our enemies" is really not fun. Especially if you are used to a modern workplace where cloud is normal it just feels like the dark ages here.. (remember 2014 when you needed to use your VPN to connect to a super slow jump host you share with 100 other people so you can get access to a server? yeah.. )

Pros: They have a very flexible culture.
Cons: The start up environment can have some people duplicating work.

Pros: Very bright, committed colleagues across all of the orgs that I’ve had the opportunity to work with. Best part of the job. It can be both invigorating and grueling to be part of Kyndryl as it tries to move from startup to non-startup mode.
Cons: Work/life balance is not good. Terrible for some employees. Regularly work 12 hour days alongside my teammates. I’m in the US. The hours that my coworkers work in India are even worse. Archaic internal processes (legacy IBM processes and tools) although there is work underway to make improvements.

Pros: Good colleagues、atmosphere、good manager、good working place
Cons: not quite good in salary

Pros: Work from home Some travel Abundant work and learning
Cons: Moving fast to transform, causing extra work and creating some chaos

Review Title: Great Company - Off to an Excellent Start
Pros:
They are serious about reducing the "red tape". My team asked for a process improvement, one we had been denied by IBM and Kyndryl executed on it immediately, taking us from a 3 page process that took close to 30 days to execute to a 1 page process that executes is just 5 to 7 days.

The best female leadership diversity I have ever seen. Am very proud to see so many woman leaders - over and over. Our day one global launch party was led by one of our female executives and when we went live on the NYSE, the balcony was full of female faces.

Really appreciate all the time and effort that is spent on making training available for all employees.

There is an excellent system for making employee referrals. It lists all available career opportunities and offers bonus dollars for those making the referral.
Cons: Made a bad choice at the end of last year and didn't grant raises. They issued raises just a couple months later and I received the best raise I have had in years. Worked at IBM 2 years and AT&T for 20 plus years.

Review Title: What's left when a great company leaves and a shell remains
Pros: work hours are day shift work from home autonomy
Cons: the ability to support my customer to the level they are accustomed to is now a vague memory of work past great IT tools to support my job have been replaced with hard to use, less effective tools management has been off shored and there is a culture divide that makes team work challenging incentives to perform better, raises, bonuses have been removed from the environment very high turnover rate at the entry level positions - all entry level positions are offshore now no clear company vision huge amount of new challenges added that reduce my ability to support our client

Pros: Pay is good, but may not be worth it depending how important it is to you to move the needle and progress.
Cons: Disorganization and lack of accountability across colleagues.
